title: Macracanthorhynchus
text:
Macracanthorhynchus, also known as the giant thorny-headed worm of swine, is a member of the 
<a href="Oligacanthorhynchidae">Oligacanthorhynchidae</a> which contains many species. One species, "M. hirudinaceus", is a <a href="parasite">parasite</a> which lives in the <a href="intestine">intestine</a>s of <a href="pig">pig</a>s and other <a href="Suidae">suids</a>, and very occasionally in <a href="human">human</a>s or <a href="dog">dog</a>s. It causes <a href="enteritis">enteritis</a>, <a href="gastritis">gastritis</a> or <a href="peritonitis">peritonitis</a>. Its <a href="Biological%20life%20cycle">life cycle</a> includes <a href="beetle">beetle</a>s of the genus "<a href="Melolontha">Melolontha</a>" as <a href="intermediate%20host">intermediate host</a>s. This species has many synonyms which include: "Echinorhynchus gigas" (Block, 1782), "Macracanthorhynchus gigas" (Block, 1782), "Echinorhynchus hirundinacea" (Palas, 1781), "Gigantorhynchus hirundinaceus" (Pallas, 1781), "Gigantorhynchus gigas" (Block, 1782), "Hormorhynchus gigas" (Block, 1782), "Taenia haeruca" (Pallas, 1776), and "Taenia hirundinaceus" (Pallas, 1781) The complete <a href="mitochondrial%20genome">mitochondrial genome</a> of "M. hirudinaceus" has been sequenced. The eggs have 4 membranes are 98 um long and have an elongation ratio of 1.85.
Another species, "M ingens", has eggs which have 3 membranes are 94 um long and have an elongation ratio of 1.66. It parasitizes the <a href="raccoon">raccoon</a> ("Procyon lotor") in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
